meta.title: Security from Zero: A Practical Guide to Security for Busy People
meta.author: Eric Higgins

parts.title: Simplifying Security for Busy People
parts.body: Security can often seem difficult and overwhelming, especially if your schedule is already packed. This book aims to simplify cybersecurity, offering practical advice without complex jargon. It targets entrepreneurs and team leaders who need easy steps to protect their business. Security is crucial from the start, and this guide shows how to incorporate simple measures into existing routines, making security as natural as exercise.

parts.title: Making a Security Work Case
parts.body: When making a case for security work, focus on resources and prioritization. Understand that you need to justify the work by demonstrating the risks, like incidents already happening. Use data to communicate urgency and scale effectively. Collaborate with sales and support to gain insights into customer security concerns. This strengthens your argument to convince executive leadership to allocate the necessary resources. Recognize that securing their support involves negotiation, so be prepared to discuss what minimal resources can target key security features or initiatives.

parts.title: Effectively Managing Security Issues with Issue Tracking Tools
parts.body: Issue tracking software (like Jira or GitHub Issues) helps organize and prioritize tasks, including security issues, making them easy to manage. The main role of these tools in a security program is to keep tasks organized and traceable, provide clear communication among team members, and assist in identifying task hierarchies. It's advised to keep a list of all issues to stay organized. Filing a ticket for every security issue, like new CVE, is crucial as it helps record all details when they're fresh in your mind. Managing these tickets involves updates on stale tickets, triaging new ones, and communicating statuses to leadership and customers. Keyword labeling (critical, high, medium, low) is used to rank issues. Delegating ticket management can boost team involvement in security. Using the same issue tracker avoids a confusion of tools, and keeping processes simple through optional fields and templates encourages issue reporting. This ensures proper tracking and resolution with streamlined, cross-linking systems for multiple team trackers.

parts.title: Planning a Security Budget
parts.body: When planning a security budget, alignment between goals, resources, and growth expectations is key. A budget should earmark funds to achieve specific goals and consider factors like short and long-term goals, input from accounting, and employee numbers. A small or even zero budget is common at the start, but understanding available resources is crucial. First-year budgets should focus on high-impact expenses, such as antivirus software, password managers, or security audits. Creating a detailed budget exercise can help clarify goals and expected costs; adjustments to include expected growth is also necessary. At the year’s end, review budget utilization to refine future planning.

parts.title: Understanding Bug Bounty Programs
parts.body: Bug Bounty Programs incentivize the public disclosure of security vulnerabilities to improve software security. Initially, unpaid researchers often got ignored or sued for reporting bugs. Netscape changed this narrative by offering monetary rewards, a practice now essential for many tech companies. Benefits of bug bounty programs include setting clear expectations for researchers, improvement in product security, and enhancing the quality of reports over time. Managed programs are recommended to prioritize and assess reports efficiently.

parts.title: The Role of Monitoring and Alerting in Security
parts.body: When improving your company's security posture, it's essential to consider logging, monitoring, and alerting systems. These tools often already exist for software engineering teams but aren't always used for security purposes. They encompass Security Information Management (SIM), Security Event Management (SEM), and Security Information and Event Management (SIEM). These systems are invaluable because they help detect potential security issues early and inform where a defensive posture is needed. They also help in reducing false positives and focusing on signal over noise to create effective security strategies. Logging creates a record of events in a server that can be referenced later, while monitoring analyzes these logs to detect any anomalies or breaches. Alerting, on the other hand, notifies relevant team members about detected events, ensuring a swift response. Setting up these systems thoughtfully can help leverage existing infrastructure while minimizing additional costs and enhancing the company's security framework. The goal is to have a proactive security approach, using monitoring to foresee potential threats and ensure the organization is prepared to respond effectively.
